subject: Re: Behavior of optional string messages for assert methods?
msgSnippet: Jason, Thanks for feedback.  Also, I agree with you David, this should be logged. ... seeing is ... class. All ... with a ... printout. ...
messageBody:
Jason,
Thanks for feedback. Also, I agree with you David, this should be logged.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
>
> Yuck.
>
> Is there a bug for this in SourceForge?
>
> David Saff
>
> jason r tibbetts wrote:
> > I agree that it looks idiotic, but the behavior that the OP is
seeing is
> > exactly how JUnit 3.8.1 has always worked /for assertions of
> > primitives/. Look at the source of the junit.framework.Assert
class. All
> > of the assert*()s that compare primitives ultimately call fail(),
with a
> > null message argument if no message was used as the first argument to
> > assert*(). This is the 'null' that you see in the test result
printout.
> > Is this horrible user feedback? Yes. Note that the assertions for
> > Strings and Objects, instead of calling fail(), throw a
> > ComparisonFailure object. This is an extension of
AssertionFailedError
> > that crafts an exception message string that's a bit more
user-friendly
> > (i.e. the infamous "expected <....> but was <...>" message).
> >
> > IIRC, the junit-addons package
> > (http://sourceforge.net/projects/junit-addons) has an alternative
Assert
> > class that prints out much nicer exception messages.
> >
> >
> >> I've never heard of such behaviour. What version of JUnit are you
using?
> >> --
> >> Stephen Smith, MEng (Wales).
> >> http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/ <http://www.stephen-smith.co.uk/>
> >>
> >> yogamatt1970 wrote:
> >> > If I leave it like this:
> >> > assertTrue(spannedString.indexOf(sample)> -1);
> >> > I see the null message when the assertion fails but if I
change it to
> >> > this:
> >> > assertTrue("hello",spannedString.indexOf(sample)> -1);
> >> > I see the message hello get printed to stout.
> >> > This seems to happen with most (if not all) of the Junit assert
> >> > methods for me.
> >> >
> >> >
> >> > --- In junit@yahoogroups.com <mailto:junit%40yahoogroups.com>,
> >> didoss@ wrote:
> >> >> What, exactly, does your assert look like your test?
> >> >>
> >> >> It sounds like you have used the signature that expects a
string and
> >> > the assertion argument(s), instead of using the one with just the
> >> > assertion argument(s),...though I've never tried it, to see if
I get
> >> > the results you are seeing, and I've never seen the results
you are
> >> > seeing to know of another reason why you would get it.
> >> >> Please paste your assertion, so that we can help you further.
> >> >>
> >> >>
> >> >> thanks,
> >> >> Dianne
> >> >>
> >> >> -------------- Original message --------------
> >> >> From: "yogamatt1970" <yogamatt1970@>
> >> >> OK, apologies in advance if this has been asked before - I
searched
> >> >> around the forum here and could not find an answer to my
question:
> >> >>
> >> >> I've noticed that if I don't supply the optional string
argument to
> >> >> many (perhaps all) of Junit's assert methods, I get an error
message
> >> >> that looks like this:
> >> >> [junit] null
> >> >> [junit] junit.framework.AssertionFailedError
> >> >>
> >> >> I find this to be confusing. However, if I include the optional
> >> >> string argument, then that message is displayed in the output.
> >> >> I have a very high opinion of the Junit framework and find it
hard to
> >> >> believe that the null message is standard behavior. It feels so
> >> >> clunky, almost as if Junit does not check to see if the optional
> >> >> argument was passed or not. My guess is that there's a property
> >> >> somewhere which allows me disable the null error but I can't
find it.
> >> >> My other option is to just add a string argument to all of the
> >> >> asserts in all of my unit tests (at this point, not that many
although
> >> >> it would still be a pain and would probably take me at least
a few
> >> > hours).
> >> >> Any and all help is appreciated.
> >>
